content:
Charismatic what is it?  has little to do with an exciting physical appearance of colorful personality: qualities that elicit short-term interst. clear vision, a quality of single-mindedness, and practical skills can be devastatingly charsmatic, provided it is matched with some success. it is an illusion in they eyes of those who see you as having what they lack. this is the guru effect. the aura you are after is not the fiery one of most charismatics. but one of incandescence, enlightenement. people are naturally drawn to those who emit happiness. maybe thye can catch it from you. let them see it in your unhurried manner, your gentle smile, your ease and comfort. keep your words vague, letting people imagine what they will. being aloof and istant only stimulates the effect. people will fight for the slightest sign of your interst. a guru is content and dtetached: a deadly charismatic combination you must learn to exploit the two great purveryors of emotion: drama and emotion. drama cuts out the useless and banal in life, focusing on moments of pity and terror. make your charitable actions dramatic, give your loing words religious import, bathe everything in rituals and myths going back to childhood. religion deals with matters of life and death. the only thing that cannot be faked is confidence. charisma depends of success the best way to maintain success, after initial charismatic rush, is to be practical and cautious.    the ugly  volatile. most often it stirs sentiments of love. but such feelings are hard to maintain. erotic fatigue: the moments after love in which you feel tired of it, resentful. at the first sign of weakness they turn on you. the love they showed before will be matched by their hatred now. the only defense is to master your charisma. too much charisma for too long creates fatigue, and adesire for calmness and order. a prophet may cquire power through his charismatic personality, he cannot survive wihtout the strength to back it up. the mass will be tired of him. this means being merciless with your enenies for as long as you retain power succeeding a Charismatic. the one who follows after a Charismatic is left with a mess, which the people do not see.  theatricality  surprisingly it is not the actor who screams the loudest or gestures the most wildy who works this magic best. but the actor who stays calm, radiating self-assuarance. the effect is ruined by trying too hard. it is essential to be self-aware, to have the ability to see yourself as others see you. De Gaulle understood that self-awareness was key to his vcharisma: he retained an Olympian composure that played beautifully agaistn the hysteria of his colleageues. when he spoke, noone bould their eyes off him. flamboyancy has nothing to do with charisma: once you know how to command attention, heigten the effect by appearing in ceremonial and reitual events that are full of exciting imagery  unihibitedness  most people are repressed and have little access to their unconscious: a problem that creats opportunities for the Charismatic. You will first have to show that you are less inhibited that your audeince: that you radiate a dangerous sexuality, have no fear of death, and delightfully spontaneous an extension of your being unihibited is a dreamlike quality in your works the repressed are rigid, their cousins is a fluidisty of body and spirit.  fervency  you need to believe in something, and to believe in it strongly enough for it to animate all yor gestures and make your eyes light up. a prerequisite for fiery belief is some great cause to rally around: a crusade. become the rallying point for people’s discontent. and show that your share non of the doubts that plague normal humans. people are more and more isolated, and we long for communcal experience. let your own fervent and contagious faith, in virtually anything, give them something to believe in.  vulnerability  displays a need for love and affection. we re open to their audience, and in fact feed off its energy. the audience in turn is electrified by the Charismatic. since charisma involves feelings akin to love, you must reveal your love for your followers. if the audience does not sense this quality in you they will turn away from you. you must never seem manipulative or needy. nothing is more seductive to people tan the feeling that they are desired.  adventurousness  unconventional. they have an air of adventure and risk that attracts the bored. be brazen and courageous in your actions. be seen taking risks for the good of others. Charismatics thrive in troubled waters. show heroism to give yourself a charism that will last you a lifetime. the slightest sign of cowardice or intimidity will ruin whatever charisma you had.  magnestism  the eyes are the most physical attribute to seduction. they reveal excitement, tension, detachment, without a word being spoken. indirect communication is critical in seduction, and also in charisma. the demeanor of charismatics maybe posed and calm, but their eyes are magnetic. they have a piercing gaze that disturbs their targets' emotions, exerting force without words or action. all of these skills are acquirable. the look does not necessarily have to be aggressive. it can also show contenetment. your eyes can emanate charisma, but they can also give you away as a faker.  the savior  Lenin alone was followed unhesistatingly as the only indisputable leader. he was a man of iron will and inmitable energy who combines fanatical faith the movement, the cause, with no less faith in himself. at a time when other politicians were scrambling deperately to adapt to the national crisis, Lenin was rock stable  the deliverer  the deliverer provides an opportunity for the release of bottled-up emotions from other people: of the hostility masked by forced politeness and smiles. dilvererers have to be one of the suffering crowd, only more so. their pain must be exemplary. the dliverer must be a living example of personal redemption.   charismatic types  joan of arc: peasant french girl who had a vision so vivid, so detailled that she could convice the king to go to war with England. they lost but see, she was a good hustler. rasputin: the authentic animal  charisma what to learn form these people  describe these things in great detail, with an air of authority, and suddenly you stand out. if your prophecy is what people want to hear, they are lilely to fall under your spell. you will create a self-fulfilling prophecy: people’s belief in you will translate into actions that help realize your visions. people are more complicated than the masks they wear in society. the man who seems so noble and gentle is probably disguising a dark side, which will often come out in strange ways. on the ohter hand, we are drawn to people who seem more comforably human, who do not bother to disguise their contradictions. a man so authentically himself, so devoid of self-conscriousness or hypocrisy, is immensely appealing. his wickedness and saintliness were so extreme that it made him seem larger than life. the essence of charisma is an overpwering emotion that comunicates itself in your gestures, in your tone of bvoice, insubtle signs that are the more powerful for being unspoken. express what others are afraid to say and they will see great power in you. say what they want to say but cannot. never be afraid of goin too far.  the olympian actor  when using it is best to radiate calmness and control. to use dramatic effects sparingly double the effectiveness of the brief moents when you raise your voice or let loose a biting joke. all this must be carefully orchestrated. the  repressed  most of us are a mix of the devil and the saint, the noble and the ignoble. and we spend our lives trying to repress the dark side. few of us can give free rein to both sides. but we can create charisma to a smaller degree by riding ourselves of self-consciousness. anything extraordinary will create charisma. a crowd or group of any sort has a unique energy. just below the surface is desire, a constant sexual excutement has to be repressed because it is socially unacceptable. your uninhibitedness will invite other people to open up, sparking a chain reaction: their excitement will in turn animate you still more.  THE STAR  mythic star  People are divided by all kinds of consciously recognized categories: race, gender, class, religion, politics. It is impossible, then, to gain power on a grand scale, or to win an election, by drawing on conscious awareness; an appeal to any one group will only alienate another. Unconsciously, however, there is much we share. All of us are mortal, all of us know fear, all of us have been stamped with the imprint of parent figures; and nothing cojues up this shared experience more than myth.
  your words and actions should invite interpretation beyond their surface appearance. you should seem to be dealing with matters of life and death, love and hate, authority and chaos.  keys to the character  form of persuasion that seeks to bypass consciousness, stirring the unconscious mind instead. we are so surrounded by stimuli that compete for our attention, bombarding us with obvious messages. we have grown increasingly cynical. learn the art of insinuation: reaching the unconscious. d

content: Those great sweeps ofsnow that stop suddenly six feet from the house . . . Thoughts that go so far. The boy gets out ofhigh school and reads no more books; The son stops calling home. The mother puts down her rolling pin and makes no more bread. And the wife looks at her husband one night at a party) and loves him no more. The energy leaves the wine) and the minister falls leaving the church. It will not come closerThe one inside moves back) and the hands touch nothing) and are safe. The father grieves fOr his son) and will not leave the room where the coffin stands. He turns away from his wife) and she sleeps alone. And the sea lifts and falls all night) the moon goes on through the unattached heavens alone. The toe of the shoe pivots in the dust . .. And the man in the black coat turns) and goes back down the hill. No one knows why he came) or why he turned away) and did not climb the hill.
summary: Those great sweeps ofsnow that stop suddenly six feet from the house . . . Thoughts that go so far. The boy gets out ofhigh school and reads no more books; The son stops calling home. The mother puts down her rolling pin and makes no more bread. And the wife looks at her husband one night at a party) and loves him no more. The energy leaves the wine) and the minister falls leaving the church.

content: Dos Donts  get drunk: alcohol interferes with the ability of prefrontal cortex neurons to communicate with one another, by disrupting dopamine receptors and blocking a particular kind of neuron called an NMDA receptor. heavy drinkers also experience the frontal lobe system souble whammy: they lose certain capabilties, such as impulse control or motor coordination or the ability to drive safely, but they arent aware that theyve lost them. overgrowth of dopaminergic neurons in the frontal lobes leads to autism, which mimics fontal lobe damage to some degree. the opposite, a reduction of dopaminergic neurons in the frontal lobes, occurs in Parkinson’s disease and ADD. solves by druges that increase dopamine in the frontal lobes.

outsiders ingroup and outgroup effects have a neurobiological basis. within an area of the brain called the medial prefrontal cortex, theres a group of neurons that fire when we think about ourselves and poeple who are like us. due to exposure. were better able to engage the medial prefrontal cortex with ingroup members because their bahaviors are easier for our brains to visualize in all their nuance. it appears that the partitioning of people into mutually exclusive categories activates the perception that ‘we’ are better than ‘they’ even when there is no rational basis for it. thats just the way ‘we’ are when we think about organizing our social world, the implication of ingroup/outgroup bias is clear. we have a stubborn tendency to misjudge outsiders and diminish our abilities to forge new, cooperative, and potentially valuable social relations. racism is a form of negative social judgement that arises from a combination of belief perseverance, outgroup bias, categorization error, and faulty inductive reasoning. in case of ingroup/outgroup bias, each group thinks of the other as homogeneous and monoithic, and each group views itself as variegated and complex the act of living in cities and towns together is an act of cooperation. various levels of gov pass laws to define civil behavior. we rely on each other not just to observe the law but to be basically helpful  tips  go to bed at the same time every nightwake up at the same time every morning set an alarm clock if you have to stay up late one night. still wake up at a fixed time in the next morning. sleep impulse control, or a combination of all 3. the tendency to procrastinate has been found to be correlated with certain traits, lifestyles, and other factors. younger and single are more likely to procrastinate. being outside in natural settings: parks, forests, the beach, the mountains, and the desert. replenished self-regulatory mechanisms in the brain. living or spending time in nature as others pursue unpleasant task in favor of those that are more fun or that yield an immediate reward.   the rest seeking procrastinators would generally rather not be exerting themselves at all. while the fun-task procrastinators enjoy being busy and active all the time. delayed gratification: activities with a long time to completion (long time to reward) are the ones more likely to be started late. and those with an immediate reward are less likely to be procrastinated humans have a low tolerance for frustration. when choosing what tasks to undertake or activities to pursue, we tend to choose not the most rewarding but the easisest. this means that unpleasant or difficult things get put off.   we tend to evaluate our self-worth in terms of our achievements. whether we lack self-confidence in general: or confidence that this particular project will turn out well. we procrastinate because that allows us to delay putting our reputations on the line until later.
 why?  our limbic system, and immediate-rewards-seeking parts of the brain contest with our prefrontal cortex. which all too well understands that consequenes of falling behind. both regions run on dopamine. but the dopamine has different actions in each. dopamine in the prefrontal cortex causes us to focus and stay on task. dopamine in the limbic system, along with the brain’s own endogenous opioids, causes us to feel pleasure. we put things off wehenver the desire for immediate pleasure wins out over our ability to delay gratification, depending on which dopamine system is in control some individuals suffer from initiaion deficits: cant start others fail to accomplish tasks on time because they cant finish maybe because of the lack of skills. maybe from perfectionism.  mindset  successful person sees each setback as an opportunity to gain additional knowlege to accomplish my goal success: ‘i thought i knew everything i needed to know to achieve my goals. but this has taught me that i dont. once i learn this, i can get back on track.’ they expect a rocky life ahead. 2 subregions involved in self-assessment and judging own performance are dorsolateral prefrontal cortex and the orbital cortex. self-confidence appears to have a genetic basis.   faulty beliefs  life should be easy our self-worth is dependent on our success if our self-confidence and the value of completing the task are both high, we’re less likely to procrastinate.  $$ \textbf{procrastination } = \frac{\text{time to complete a task x distractability} }{\text{self-confidence x task value}} $$

scenarios with our left prefrontal cortex and anterior cingulate) second phase, we need to relax, let go of the problem, and let networks in the right hemisphere take over neurons in the right hemisphere are more broadly tuned, with longer branches and more dendritic spines. less precise but more connected. the moment preceding insight is accompanied by a burst of gamma waves. which bind together disparate neural networks, effectivelt binding thoughts that were seemingly unrelated into a coherent new whole.  maximize creativity  flow state: different state of being during flow, two key regions of the brai ndeactivate: the portion of the prefrontal cortex responsible for self-criticism, and the amygdala, the brain’s fear center.  flow state  attention is focused on a limited perceptual field, and that field receives your full concentration and complete investment action and awareness merge.you cease thinking about yourself as separate from the activity or the world, and you don’t think of your actions and your perceptions as being distinct: what you think becomes what you do. during flow, you experience freedom from worry about failure; you are aware of what needs to be done, but you don’t feel that you are doing it. the ego is not involved and falls away completely. flow is a lack of distractibility: the same old distractions are there, but we’re not tempted to attend to them. we monitor our performance without the kinds of self-defeating negative judgments flow states don’t occur for just any old task or activity. they can occur only when one is deply focused on the task, when the task requires intense concentration and commitment, provides immediate feedback, and is perfectly matched to one’s skill level if the task you are engaged in is too simple, holding no challenge, i’ll get bored. that boredom will break my attention to the task, and my mind will wander into the default mode. if the task is too difficult and holds too many challenges. i’ll become frustrated and experience anxiety. the greater my skill is, the greater the opportunity to achieve flow. the flow state is characterized by a total lack of conscious awareness, subconsciously, and then the more easily you can disengage your conscioys mind, your ego, and other enemies of flow. easier for those who have invested a great deal of time to a given dopamin  what flow means  high level of engagement. info access and processing seem effortless. skills we didn’t know we had emerges. with no need to exercise self-control to stay focused, we free neural resources to the task at hand. during flow states, we no longer need to exert ourselves to stay on task: it happens automatically as we enter this specialized attentional state. it takes less energy to be in flow than to be distracted. this is why flow states are periods of great productivity and efficiency flow is a chemically different state. flow occurs when you are not explicitly thinking about what you’re doing. your brain is in a special mode of activity in which procedures and operations are performed automatically without your having to exert conscious control. trying to think about what most of us are conditioned to devalue happiness right from childhood.
 we should try to not get distracted from making happiness-enhancing decisions  7 sins, 7 good habits prioritizing, but not pursuing, happiness chasing superiority  as children, we are exposed to feedback that tells us whether we are superior or inferior to others around us. consider the impact of failing to acquire a girlfriend or boyfriend when everyone else has one.  reasons we seek superiority  we learn that valedictorians get better scholarships, CEOs get higher wages, and top entertainers get better deals and more magazine covers. we also learn about the importance of superioirty from TV and magazines, which selectively cover stories of successes rather than failures we come to tether our self-esteem to being superioir. when we learn that the amount of love and attention we get from others depends on how well we stack up to our peers, we internalize the need for superiority to such an extent that we seek it even if the others aren’t around to judge us. rooted in our desire to figure out whether we are making adequate progress toward cherished goals.   As humans, one of our most important goals is mastery: the desire to become increasingly competent or effective at something.
  being ‘superioir’ gives us the autonomy or freedom to be who we are; higher-status individuals don’t feel the need to watch what they say or restric their behaviors. superiority is about the need for approval. it is about self-esteem. it is aboyt mastery. and about autonomy.  does being superior make me happier  yes. participants made to feel superior displayed more positive expressions, while those made to feel inferior displayed more negative ones. happy people are generally more successful. lower in status are more prone to falling sick, are sick for longer periods of time, have shorter life spans, and suffer more emotional negativity than those higher in status. those higher in status perceive themselves to have greater autonomy and control over their own decisions and this makes them happier it’s impossible to come up with objective yardsticks for assessone one’s standing relative to others in any domain. almost everyone believes they are better tan the average person on positive traits like professionalism, warmth, and kindness. the proxy yardsticks of  why materialism lowers happiness  the catch with earning more is that expenses catch up with earnings. we adapt to new levels of wealth, power, and fame means that we need to become increasingly wealthy, powerful, and famous over the course of our lives to maintain high levels of happiness. adaptation is a big reason why materialism diminishes happiness levels in the long run. promotes self-centeredness and lowers compassion, making others less likely to cooperate with materialistic people, leading them to be less happy in the long run. lower compassion leads us to compromise on things that actually bring joy and happiness - things like haning out with freinds and family or contributing to society. compared to nonmaterialistic people, materialistic people are more likely to suffer from mental disorders tethering one’s self-worth to being better than others can lead to obsessing about the implications of failing to achieve this goal, making one more vulnerable to depression. those with a high need for superiority may end up sacrificing long-term learning and growth for the sake of short term boosts in hubristic pride. the detrimental effect it has on the quality of relationships. those who pursue superiority tend to be takes and takers aren’t well liked. people are much more likely to cooperate with givers the less attention you pay to how much better or worse than others you are, the happier you are likely to be. the more you compare yourself with others, the less happy you will be.  mitigating the need for superiority  not only is the need for superiority hardwired in us, but most of us are also socialized to pursue it. being superior makes us happier, pursuing superiority lowers happiness mitigate the misconception about the need for superiority. many of us believe the need for superiority is an important determinant of success. this is mostly wrong. why?? the need for superiority helps us get started. however, once we start a task, that needs becomes a hindrance.  materialism Scale  I admire people who own expensive homes, cars, and clothes. 3 Some of the most important achievements in life include acquiring material possessions. 3 I don’t place much emphasis on the amount of material objects people own as a sign of success.* 6 The things I own say a lot about how well I’m doing in life. 7 I like to own things that impress people. 4 I don’t pay much attention to the material objects other people own.* 3 I usually buy only the things I need.* 2 I try to keep my life simple, as far as possessions are concerned.* 2 The things I own aren’t all that important to me.* 7 I enjoy spending money on things that aren’t practical. 1 Buying things gives me a lot of pleasure. 1 I like a lot of luxury in my life. 7 I put less emphasis on material things than most people I know.* 4 I have all the things I really need to enjoy life.* 2 My life would be better if I owned certain things I don’t have. 6 I wouldn’t be any happier if I owned nicer things.* 7 I’d be happier if I could afford to buy more things. 7 It sometimes bothers me quite a bit that I can’t afford to buy all the things I’d like.7
summary:
most of us are conditioned to devalue happiness right from childhood.
 we should try to not get distracted from making happiness-enhancing decisions  7 sins, 7 good habits prioritizing, but not pursuing, happiness chasing superiority  as children, we are exposed to feedback that tells us whether we are superior or inferior to others around us. consider the impact of failing to acquire a girlfriend or boyfriend when everyone else has one.

when we were young. when we wanted to leave our parents side to go explore new things. we also wanted to have the security to fall back on. so we leave our parents' side.
 if our parents prevented us from doing that, we grow up to be isolaters the opposite would be parents who push us away when we came running to them for comfort. we grow up to be fusers fusers want to ‘do things together’. if people fail to show up at the appointed time, they feel abandoned. ironically. fusers and isolaters tend to grow up and marry each other.  parents fear of engulfment  i fear that if i always come runing back to my mom i will be trapped in a symbiotic union forever when i marry, my need to be a distinct ‘self’ will be on the top of my hidden genda i keep people at a distance cause i need to have ‘a lot of space’ around me. i want the freedom to come and go. i don’t want to be ‘pinned down’ to a single relationship.  the lost self  socializaion create emotional injury. we are susceptible to our parents' beliefs hidden from consciousness. when we complain that we “can’t think'“can’t feel anything” “can’t dance”, etc.   The desire for a powerful and unihibited ego may seem to us intelligible. s shown by the times that we live in, it is in the profoundest sense antogonistic to civilization – Freud –

The two women chatted while the little boy crawled around on the deck, happily digging his fingers into the warm soil of the flowerpots. After about half an hour, the baby became hungry, and Chris put him to her breast. My friend noticed that as the baby nursed he developed a miniature erection. Apparently nursing was such a sensual experience that he felt pleasure throughout his body. Instinctively, the little boy reached down to touch his genitals. Unlike most mothers, Chris did not pull his hand away. Her baby was allowed to feel the warm sun on his naked skin, nurse from his mother’s breasts, have an erection, and add to his pleasure by holding on to his penis.
  it is normal and naturla for an infant to want to have good feelings, but we rearly allow it. When we were young, there were many, many times when limits were placed on our sensuality.  forbidden feelings  our emotions were another prime candidate for socialization. parents encouraged sociable behaviors like laughter and discouraged it is rare for parents to validate a child’s anger. if i react to my daughter’s anger with something like:  “I can see that you’re mad. You don’t want to do whatI ask. but i am the parent and you are the child and you need to do what i say.”
  having her anger acknowledged would contribute to her sense of self.  tools of repression  conditioned by our parents to be aware of acceptable behaviors. we come to the conclusion that some thoughts and feelings are so unacceptable that they should be eliminated, so we construct an imaginary parent in our head to police our thoughts and activities, a part of the mind that psychologists call the ‘superego’ whenever a child has a forbidden thought or indulges in an ‘unacceptable’ behavior, he expereinces a self-administered jolt of anxiety. this is so unpleasant that the child puts to sleep some of those forbidden parts of himself. he represses them. the ultimate price of his obedience is a loss of wholeness  the false sense  we create a ‘false self’ a character structue that serves a double purpose: it camouflages those parts of his being that he has repressed and protects him from further injury. when he gets into a love relationship, he will criticize his partner for her desire for intimacy and her intact sexuality.  we adopt negative traits from our parents  why don’t people simply tell each other in plain English that they want more affection or attention or lovemaking or freedom or whatever when we were young, we were taught that the only way to get what we want is to provoke people around us this primitive method of signaling distress is characteristic of most couples immersed in a power struggle even though their partners react to these maneuvers with renewed hostility, they  stages of the power struggle   it followws a predictable course, one that happens to parallel the well-documented stages of grief in a dying or bereaved person.
  first comes the shock, that horrifying moment of truth w find a way tohen a window opens and a wrenching thought invades your consciousness: this is not the person I thought I had married.
  at that instant you assume that married life is going to be a continuation of the loneliness and pain of childhood.
  after shock comes denial.
  after that you feel betrayed. you are in pain, and the degree of your pain is the degree of the disparity between your earlier fantasy of your partner and your partner’s emerging reality.
  fourth stage: bargaining. this stage goes like this: if you will give up your drinking, i will be more interested in sex.
  last stage is despair. no hope. 5% find a way to resolve the power struggle.
  we enter relationships with the unconscious assumption that our partner will become a surrogate parent and make up for all the deprivation of our childhool. all we have to do to be healed is to form a close, lasting relationship
  the partner is perceived as witholding love. we begin to hurt each other, or deny each other pleasure and intimacy, in hopes of having their partners respond with warmth and love.
  becoming conscious  Seldom or never does a marriage develop into an individual relationship smoothly without crisis. There is no birth of consciousness without pain. C.G.Jung
 reromanticizing  through daily repetitions of psitive behaviors, your old brain begins to perceive your partner as ‘someone who nurtures me.’ your old brain associates your partner as a wellspring of life. this opens ways for intimacy, which is only possible in a context of pleasure and safety it helps people erode the infantile belief that their partners can read their minds. when they fail to satisfy their secret desires, they assume that they are deliberately depriving them of pleasure. most relationships are run like a commodities market, with loving behaviors the coin in trade. this comes straight out of the hood: our childhood. when we were infants, love came without price tags. we want to be loved and cared for without having to do anything in return. when our partners grant us caring behaviors independent of our actions, our need for unconditional love appears to be satisfied. often, partners in a relationship cater to their own needs and preferences.  do unto others as they would have you do unto them random reinforcement  a pleasurable action loses its effectiveness if it’s repeated with predictable regularity. gifts are so customary that they are almost taken for granted
summary: we all started out life whole and vital. To one degree or another, we were all wounded by our caretakers' intrusiveness or neglect. We experienced a primitive anxiety: the world is not a safe place. When we are adults, capable of keeping ourselves fed and warm and dry. When our partners are hostile or unhelpful, a silent alarm is triggered deep in our brains that fills us with the fear of death.

content:
in relationships, if both parties are willing to hang in there, pay attention, and change direction when we make mistakes, we can improve the relationship.
step one: look at my bids   what makes marriages succeed or fail? self-disclosure: a person’s willingness to reveal his or her most guarded, personal thoughts and experiences to another person.
  ‘after collecting and viewing hundereds of hours of videotape, i found very few examples of self-disclosure. there were a few heart-to-heart exchanges about broken dreams, hidden fears, or unfulfilled sexual desires.
  maybe it’s not the depth of intimacy in convo that matters. it doensn’t even matter wheter couples agree or disagree. maybe the important thing is how people pay attention to each other.
  the topic of convo hardly matters in couples’ willingness to connect.
   by choosing to turn toward, turn away, or turn against each other’s bids for connection - no matter how ordinary or small - we establish a foundation that could determine the future success or failure of their relationships
  the importance of playfulness in people’s bids.
  people who make playful bids and turn toward one another’s bids enthusaistically during everyday conversations have more access to humor later on, when they get into an argument
  responding with good humor has become such a habit in their relationships it’s always at the top of their bag of tricks
  how bids work  the closer we feel to others, the more intense, frequent, or demanding our bids for emotional connection with them mayne . we typically ask first for help with matters that require the least time attention risk or intimacy    typical ladder of needs within a friendship  small talk humor friendly gossip affection support problem solving connection  what do bids look like  thoughts feelings observations opinions invitations  nonverbal bids  affectionate touching back-slap, handshake, pat, squeeze, kiss, hug, back or shoulder rub facial expression smile, blowing a kiss, rolling or eyes, sticking out our tongue playful touching affliating gestures vocalizing  fuzzy budding  the most common is to avoid emotional risk. openly bidding for connection can make us feel vulnerable. in career and mating situations, our hearts and egos are on the line. subtle dynamics of bidding: bids can also be hard to decipher when the bidder doesn’t ack his or her own needs for connection (this is so me) temper tantrums, crying fits, belligerence, and sassiness could be bids for conection. children do those things to look for emotional bond with people who can help them feel more adults can express their need for connection in the same confused way instead of making ordinary bids for connection we keep our longing for afffection and attention to ourselves we want to feel close to the person we love but we are very ineffective in the way we do  why?  making ambiguous bids to avoid vulnerability or emotional risk unintentional poor communication, such as inexplicit language framing bids in negative ways that are hard for others to hear or accept  responses  turn toward the bid: respond positively turn away from it: avoid turn against it: outright rejection      Turning-toward responses Turning-away responses Turning-against responses     How they appear Passive Preoccupied Contemptuous: put-downs, insults    Low-energy Disregarding: irrelevant, response or no response belligerent: provocative, combative    Attentive: validation, opinions, thoughts, feelings, questions Interrupting: introducing unrelated information or a counterbid contradictory: arguing    High-energy: full focus, enthusiasm, empathy mindless or intentional domineering: controlling, overbearing      critical: character attacks, blaming      defensive: fake helplessness, “victim” stance   How it affects relationships More bidding and responding Less bidding Less bidding    Growth and development of relationship Increased conflict Avoidance of conflict     Hurt feelings, loss of confidence Suppressed feelings     Relationship ends sooner rather than later Relationships end, but may take a while    positive response to bids passive  one or two word comment gesture  low energy response  few words or a questions to clarify the bid  attentive responses  involving opinions, thoughts, and feelings validating funny pointed questions might involve action  high energy responses  full attention with good eye contact. usually enthusiastic involve humor, kidding, or affection sincere empathy involve broad physical gestures like big hugs, ceremonious kisses, enthusiastic handshakes, or mock sparring. it tells the other person   I hear you I’m interested in you i understand (or would like to) im on your side id like to help you (whether i can or not) id like to be with you () i accept you (even if i dont accept all your behavior)    when you turn toward a bid, it helps the bidder to feel good about themselves. the bidder welcomes more interaction, leading to mor ebids and more positive responses from both sides
  leads to growth and development of healthy partnership
  lead to fewer conflicts, because the partners are having conversations they need to have
  siblings who turn toward one another in conversation are more likely to maintain close, supportive, satisfying relationships
  form more productive work teams, with higher morale
  such playfulness is extremely good for relationships and it only requires willingness to turn toward another sense of silliness.
  not all bids for connection are good-natured and playful. we can sometimes camouuflage our bids in expressions of anger, fear and sadness. once i recognize them, i’ve got to muster the patience, creativity, and trust it takes to turn toward the bidder with a helpful response
  if you want to build solid, long-term relationships, i’ve got to be willing to turn toward each other’s bids  we long for relationships with people who will stick by us even when we’re tired, crabby, fearful, depressed, or frustrated the less people turn toward one another, the less satisfying their relationships are a long story of turning toward one another if you want to build a deeper emotional connection with somebody, turn toward that person as often as you can this depends on how comfortable each of you feels with the level of independence and intimacy in your relationship adult-child relationships children are often less reciprocal than adults. be patient and keep responding positively to the child’s bids for attention, because it will pay off in the long run. make it a point to turn toward people with fun-loving, high-energy responses when you can this type of enthusiastic, positive response has an impect on people’s ability to access humor  negative responses to bids  we want to gain more autonomy in a relationship turning away helps us to regulate the balance between freedom and interdependence. if you find yourself in a relationship where either one of you is regularly turning away, look carefully at your intentions. if either of you is turning away in order to gain more autonomy in the relationship, it’s important to talk about our relative needs for independence.  preoccupied responses disregarding interrupting  people rarly intend to be malicious or mean-spirited when they turn away. they’re often operating on ‘autopilot’ remedied by being more conscious of our interactions  the message it sends  i dont care about your bid i want to avoid your bid im not interested in your interests ive got more important things on my mind im too busy to pay attention to your bid your bid is not worth my time i want to be more independent than you want me to be  how do people respond to that bid   most people feel hurt. they may experience feelings of loneliness, isolation, and rejection. theres a little kid inside all of us that feels that way when our bids are ignored or dismissed
  a person may feel so distressed that he becomes hypervigilant or oversensitive to insult
  when somebody turns away from a bid, the bidder loses confidence and self-esteem
  they dont get puffed up with anger; they dont get indignant; they just seem to fold in on themselves. they feel defeated. they give up.
  feeling discouraged once their bids for connection have been rejected or ignored, people rearely re-bid. even in satisfied relationships, couples dont even rebid. if this hopeless attitude becomes dominant, theres less bidding, less opportunity for connection
  habitually turning away can eventually destroy relationships.
  dismissed bidder typically gets fed up. forming a pattern of attack and defend.
  adults in the family dont mean to neglect their kids or cause them harm but theyre so consumed by their own problems that every interaction with their kids amounts to telling them to be quiet or go away.
  start paying more attention to the details of her boys' lives: make a concertaed daily effort to offer them praise for the things they were doing right, and to ask them about their activities in a way that showed she was really listening
  the more people turn away from one anotherm the more conflict they’ll have to contend with later on. the more they turn toward one another’s bids, the less contentios their relationships will be
  you can’t make a habit of turning away and expect the relationship to survive
   turn against bids for connection  theses responses make the bidder feel hurt and rejected if the respondent holds a psition of power over the bidder, the bidder may even become anxious or afraid, which leades to suprressing feelings and avoiding conflict. its not unusual for people to remain in such suppressed, conflict-avoiding relationships for a long time at some point, bidders stop the biddiding and partners dirft apart. even when they stay in the relationship, they may quit interacting with each other altogether  contemptuous reponses  entail hurtful, disrespecting comments aimed at the person bidding for connection. thoses put-downs are delivered with an air of superioirty, as if the speaker wants to put some distance between the bidder and the biddee, and intentional insults will do the trick  belligerent responses  provocative or combative. a sense that the speaker is looking for a fight. they would argue with whatever the bidder says. involve unfair teasing or a dare  contradictory responses  less hostile but still blocks the bidder’s attempt to connect  domineering responses  the goal is to get the bidder to withdraw, retreat, or submit  critical responses  broad-based attacks on a bidder’s character  defensive responses  create a sense of separation by allowing the speaker to relinquish responsibility for matters at hand. they may have simply developed a personal style of relating thats crabby or irritable often its a spillover of self-criticism that has its origins in the distant past. the problem may also be a biologically based irritability that is chemically related to depression  the kind of message it sends  your need for attention makes me angry i feel hostile toward you i dont respect you i dont value you or this relationship i want to hurt you i want to drive you away  exercise: create an emotion log  document my progress toward impriving emotional communication  answers these questions  what did i notice today about the way i make bids for connection with impoortant people in my life how did i feel about the way people responded to my bids did i notice anybody turning toward? turning away? turning against? what did that behavior look like? was there anything about the way i made my bid that might have affected their choice in turning? is there anything i might do differently next time? what did i notice today about the way i responded to other people’s bids for connection? did i notice myself turning toward, turning away, or turning against other people? what did that behavior look like?  was there something about the way that person made his or her bid that affected my choice in turning? can i make a different choice> what would happen if i made a different choice?    difference between men and women  husbands in happy marriages turned toward their sposes with much greater frequency than husbands in unhappy marriages but wives turned toward their partners with the same frequency whether their marraiges were happy or not men may hold a significant key to determining whether or not their marriages will succeed. in partnerships where spouses turned away from each other’s bids, husbands and wives are likely to get hostile with one another during disagreements in marriages where partners turned against each other, husbands typically suppressed their feelings or became hostile. wives suppressed their feelings women whose husbands consistently turn against their bids may simply feel too frightened understress, men tend to become more irritable and critical than women  ay yo man  ignored when i need attention the most: 2 this person often doesn’t notice me: 1 this person usually doesn’t have a clue to what im feeling: 2 i try but not successul in obtaining the social support i need in this relationship: 2 this person should know what i need without my saying explicitly: 2 difficulty getting a meaningful conversaion going with this person: 2 trouble getting emotionally close to this person: 2 if this person cant tell what i need, i withdraw: 2 this person too busy to be emotionally available to me: 2 this person cant tell what i need or want: 2 this person often takes the focus off me and puts it to her: 2 o feel excluded by this person: 2 accumulate > 6: bid in a way that keeps my needs hidden and unknown my needs are neglected: 2 i get mad when i dont the attention i need: -2 i let her know in certain terms: -2 i can take so much being ignored, then i blowup: -2 i believe in strongly and assertively asking for what i need: -2 find myself becoming irritable: 2 i get so frustrated because i have to demand what i need:0 i feel irritated that this person isnt on my side 0 i have to let her know she isnt being a team player -2 i cant get close to this person 2 lower than 6: its easier for the other person to hear and understand what i need i have trouble getting this person to listen to me: 0 i have trouble gettings person to trust me: 2 i find it difficult content:
Principles of digital minimalism clutter is costly optimization is important Thoreau economics The cost of a thing is the amount of life required to be exchanged for it immediately or in the long run.
radical rethinking of the consumerist culture.
 who could justify trading a lifetime of stress and backbreaking labor for better ‘stuff’ Thoreau’s new economics was devaloped in an industrial age, but his insigts apply to our life. maintaining an active presence on Twitter open up an interesting new connection or expose me to an idea I hadn’t heard before. but we have to balance this porfit against the costs measured in terms of our life. how much of my time and attention that I have to sacrifice to earn the small profit of occasional connections and new ideas that is earned by cultivating a presence on Twitter. it would be way too high  costs compound  combining different media platforms would result in a high cost of life. the return on investments of my presence on those social media is almost nothing. we have to treat the minutes of our life as a concrete and valuable substance.  the most valuable substance we possess. the cumulative cost of noncrucial things we clutter our lives with can far outweigh the small benefits each individual piece of clutter promises. Return Curve   law of diminishing returns: at a high level, investing more resources into a process cannot indefinitely improve its output - eventually approach a natural limit and yield diminish return
  consider the energy invested in trying to improve the value these processes return in my life. reading the news help me stay informed about current politicl climate, but at some point I’ll have to pay for this level of being informed with my attention, while gaining non-valuable marginal returns.
  most people invest very little in these types of optimizations.
  large attention economy companies dont wants us thinking about optimization. these corporations make more money the more time you spend engaged with their products. if i think these services as a collection features which i can individually find elsewhere. i
    central idea of minimalism. less is more. think about it. if i mindlessly use my device. im outsourcing my attention autonomy to an attention company.  digital declutter  thirty day break from optional technologies afterward, reintroduce those technology, evaluating what values do these technologies provide.  rules determine which techonologies are optional  games are optional tiktok is optional youtube videos  youtube videos?  Yes. Youtube video. Most of the time I go on Youtube I do it out of habit. Compusively. Unknowingly. How to stop? First I have to determine what kind of value I get out of watching those youtube videos. Education. Entertainment. Distraction. What kind of education? Bodybuilding lessons. Diet. Lifestyle. Fashion. What kind of entertainment? Classical music. Lofi. Meme music. Chance to come across new channels that really jive with my vibe. Are there good values? Yes. Should I stop it? I don’t know. I feel like they don’t take up that much of my time? How do you know concretely? Maybe I should track my time using Youtube. Hypotheticlly. If youtube doesn’t provide that much value in exchange for my lifetime. How do I ease my transition to a more productive channel? So the value that Youtbe provide can literally be found anywhere else. But they have a competitive advantage of: easily digestible content, superior recommendation features which show videos I might be interested in. Okay I’ll shoot my shot. Books. As long as I have determined what kind of knowledge that I want to learn I can literally learn from the best from reading books. People. There are experts in real life. Here’s the catch, the most prolific, most important people are not very accessible in real life. So there’s youtube videos of them watching. So what I want to do is build a coachable personality? So that peole WANT TO invest their time in me. They want to invest in my success in real life. Okay I’ll add that to my to do list. Also I watch youtube so that I don’t have to deal with my problem.  concise version  determine optional technologies take 30 day break. see which technology is useful.  spend time alone  dealing with people might be the biggest drain on your time and energy. alright im gonna digress so i can add my value by showing people that dealing with me will help them recuperate those precious those energy. I can enjoy solidue in a crowded place. solitude can be disturbed in the form of reading a book, listening to a podcst, watching TV, or performing just about any activity. solitude requires me to move past reacting to information created by other people and focus instead on my own thoguhts and experiences.   All of humanity’s problems stem from man’s inability to sit quietly in a room alone. - Blaise Pascal-
  I have read abundance of fine things on the subject of solitude… I acknowledge solitude an agreeable refreshment to a busy mind. - Ben Franklin-
  Edward Gibbon lived a solitary life. but he was very productive and happy. A great deal of time alone is the common factor among creative people. the ability to be alone is a rejection of close bonds. it helps build appreciation for interpersonal connections when they do occur.   We enter solitude, in which also we lose loneliness -Wendell Berry
 Solitude deprivation  oh my god. we allow headphones to provide background noise for our entire day. it undermines our time alone with our own thoughts. Spotify provides me the ability to be CONSTANTLY distracted from my own mind. it is pushing us toward a newly alienated phase in our relationship with our own minds. the smartphone provided a new technique to banish these remaining slivers of solitude: a quick glane we’ve been sold the idea that more connectivity is better than less. without solitude, I lose the ability to clarify hard problems, regulate my emotions, build moral courage, strengthen relationships. if i suffer from chronic solitude deprivation, the quality of my life degrades. smartphones make you anxious. humans are not wired to be constantly wired  practice 1 leave my phone at home practice 2 take long walks  walk in scenic places without headphones. time doing this is an investment.  practice 3 write letters to yourself dont click like??  man is by nature a social animal.social cognition: when given downtime, our brain defaults to thinking about our social life. people are naturlaly interested in their own social life. social media makes me feel both connected and lonely, happy and sad. the more you use social media to interact with your network, the less time you devote to offline communication. there exists a tradeoff. using social media tends to take pepole away from the real world socializing thats massively more valuable. the small boosts i receive from posting on a friend’s wall or liking their latest Ig photo can’t come close to compensating for the large loss experience by no longer spending real world time with that same friend. IRL interactions require our brains to process large amounts of info about subtle analog cues such as body language, facial expressions, and voice tone. digital tools underutilize our social processing networks. humans are naturally biased toward activities that require less energy in the short term. even if it’s more harmful in the longterm. so we end up texting our sibling instead of calling them on the phone. or liking a picture of a friend’s new baby instead of stopping by to visit. its difficult to reist checking a device in the middle of a conversation. our dumb brain cant distinguish betwee nthe importance of the person in the room with us and the new person who just us a new text. novel tools are engineerd to hijack our primitive brain, having a very addictive allure. if i spend multiple hours a day compulsively clicking and swiping. theres much less free time left for slower interactions. we are also delusional in thinking that we’re actually building or maintaining our relationships. making further action unnecessary. conversation is what counts. those whose relationship with you only exists on social media: let them go.  reclaiming conversation  face-to-face conversation is the most human and humanizing thing we do. fully present to one another, we learn to listen. its where we develop the capacity for empathy. its where we experience the joy of being heard, of being understood. young employees retreat to email because the thought of an unstructured conversation terrifies them, and uncessary office tensions that fester when communication shifts from nuanced conversation to ambiguous connection f2f convo unfolds slowly. it teaches patience. we attend to tone and nance. when we communicate on our digital devices, we learn different habits.  not anti-technology. it’s pro-convo  anything textual or non-interactive – all social media, email, text, instant message, doesnt count as conversation and should instead be categorized as mere connection.a logistical role. as in. it should be used to set up and arrange conversation. or to efficiently transfer practical onfo. connection MUST BE a supporter to conversation.   real conversation takes time  conversation is the good stuff. it is what we crave as humans and what provides us with the sense of community and belonging necessary to thrive you cannot expect an app dreamed up in a dorm room, or among pingpong tables of a silicon valley incubator to replace the types of rich interactions to which we’ve painstakingly adapted over millennia. our sociality is simply too complex to be outsourced to a social network or reduced to instant messages and emojis.  practice 4 consolicate texting  phones have become woven into a fraught sense of obligation in friendship. the more we text the less necessary you’ll deem real conversation and when i get the chance to actually talk i’ll compulsively check my phone keep do not disturb mode on my default  practice 5 hold conversation office hours  tell my friends and acquaintances that i’ll be able to talk to them at a certain time. no need to schedule literally just call me at that time.  reclaim leasure  the best and most pleasant life is the life of the intellect - mf Aristotle it’s easy to fill the gaps between work and caring for my self and sleep by pulling a smartphone or tablet, and numbing myself with mindless swiping and tapping.  bennet principle financial independece: my assets produce enough income to cover my living expenses. when i achieve FI, i have more leisure hours to fill than the average person. so theres a community behind this movement and they provide valuable insights into high value leisure.
passive leisure activities associated with young men  palying video games, watching sports, web surfing, long evenings at the bar.   when we are provided large amounts of leisure time, we often voluntarily fill these hours with strenuous activity. Inactivity leads to depressive boredom.   I wish to preach, not the doctrine of ignoble ease, but the doctrine of the strenuous life. – teddy roosevelt
  hours should be put to use on demanding and virtuous leisure activities. Expending more energy in my leidure will end up energizing me more. That’s the old entrepreneurial adage “You have to spend money to make money” several hours of idle watching and screen tapping will make us more fatiged than when we began  craft  many of us experience thw world largely through a screen. we live in a world that is working to eliminate touch as one of our sense. when we use craft to leave the virtual world of the screen. a deep activity that requires a lot of effort like writing a piece of computer code  fix or build something every week  handy: comfortable picking up a new physical skill when needed. for most people its no longer essential for either their professional or home lives to function smoothly.  practice 6 schedule my low quality leisure  schedule in advance the time i spend on low quality leisure.  practice 7 join something  structured social interactions: important. acting on this knowledge requires hard work. join organizations that bring interesting people together for useful ends. if we can’t find such gatherings, we should create them from scratch. listlessness and boredom are not acceptable join clubs first and work out the other issues later  practice 8 follow leisure plans  high achievers are meticulous strategists. they lay out a vision for what they;re trying to accomplish on multiple different time scalesm connecting high-level ambition to decisions about daily actions. without a well considered approach to high quality leisure, our commitments will degrade because of the firction of daily life.  season leisure plan weekly leisure plan  get into the habit of creating detailed plans for my week. Oh my god im so behind in everything im scared. dont worry about rigid timetable.  join the attention resistance practice 7 delete social media from my phone practice 8 turn my devices into single purpose computers practice 9 use social media like a professional embrace slow media  the right response to digital bombardment is mindful media low information diet decide how and when we consume media  pracice 10 dumbdown my smartphone -

content:
we all have maps. a comprehensive understanding of the world. transference is the problem of using our simplistic childhood’s map to navigate the world. we fail to recognize. most people opt for a life of very limited honesty and openness and relative closedness, hiding themselves and their maps from the world.
the rewards of the difficult life of honesty and dedication to the truth commensurate the demands.
by exposing my map to other people, i can be challenged and grow as a person. can establish and maintain intimate relationships. no need to hide. secure and proud in the knowledge that they help illuminate. energy required for self-discipline and honesty is far less than the energy required for secretiveness. more honest, easier to be honeset. through the exercise of their courage to live in the open, they become free from fear.

dont confuse goals with desires
most problems are potential improvements list my problems.
if i cant identify my problems thats because either i lack the skill or lack the will :)
the problems are harsh reality, very painful to look at. so i cope my subconsciously put them out of sight to make them out of mind
i defintely worry about appearing to not have problems than about not achieving my desired results.
so what i do is avoid recognizing that my mistakes and/or weaknesses are causing the problems
are there any problems that im not perceptive enough to see.
some people are unable to distinguish big problems from small ones. this is me. my carelessness has turned my life into a mess.
try to remain centered and logical its very easy to react emotionally, seek sympathy. i have to feel the pain, the kind of pain that will test my character and reward me if i push through them.
my impediments are due largely to issues of will: unwillingness to confront what/ is really happening  lack of skill or innate talent: have others point out problems to me and myself objectively consider whether what they say is true. problems due to inadequte skill might then be solved with training, problems from innate weaknesses might “be overcome with assistance or role changes”  dont confuse problems with causes? identify the problems, then DO NOT TOLERATE THEM  might be due to thinking they can’t be solved or not caring enough about solving them  how much am i tolerating problems?  people who are good at this step: identifying and not tolerating problems  relationships between steps  goals are the sole purpose of designs and tasks. ask why to connect tasks and goals. stick too rigidly to specified tasks and are not commited enough to achieving their goals.  ask myself what i want, then ask ‘what is true, then asks ‘what should be done about it’
ask myself what is my biggest weakness that stands in the way of what i want
everyone has weaknesses. successful people find and address them.
society has taught us that having weaknesses is bad. so finding our own weaknesses very painful.
i can only get what i want out of life i can open-mindedly reflect, with the help of others, on what is standing in my way and then deal with it
understand what i am weak at and successfully compensate for that weakness by seeking help.
trust in truth  realize that i have nothing to fear from truth be extremely open have integrity and demand it from others never say anything about a person you wouldn’t say to them directly. dont try people without accusing them to their face. dont let ‘loyalty’ stand in the way of truth and openness be radically transparent record almost all meetings and share them with all relevant people dont tolerate dishonesty dont believe when someone caught being dishonest says they have seen the light and will never do that sort of thing again

content:
The score functionused to measure the quality of different tree structures is a general miscalassification loss function, defined as $\sum_{i=1}^nC(y(i),\hat{y}(i))$
 $C(y(i),\hat{y}(i))$ is the loss incurred when the class label for the ith data vector, y(i) is predicted by the tree to be $\hat{y}(i)\ne y(i)$  cross-validation  partitions the training data into a subset for building the tree then estimates the misclassifcation rate on the remaining validation subset. this partitioning is repeated multiple times on different subsets and the misclassfication rates are then averaged to yield a cross-validation estimate of how well a tree of a particular size will perform on new, unseen data.  characteristics  estimate the performance of any tree model on data not used in the construction of the tree $\rightarrow$ providees an estimate of generalization performance.

Linux memory types There are three types of memory, and one is optional.
 physical memory, a limited resource where code and data must reside when executed or referenced. optional swap file: where modified (dirty) memory can be saved and later retrieved if too many demands are made on physical memory big boy virtual memory: unlimited resource intended to   abstraction: free from physical memory addresses/limits isolation: every process in a separate address space sharing: single mapping can serve multiple needs flexibility: assign a virtual address to a file

content:
Chapter 1 Introduction is an interdisciplinary exercise, can be thought of as statistics, database, or machine learning problem.
from observational datasets to find unsuspected relations and to summarize the data in novel ways
deals with data that have already been collected for some purpose other than the data mining analysis. This is different from statistics, which data are often colleted by using efficient strategies to answer specific answers.
Models and Patterns Include linear equations, rules, clusters, graphs, tree structures, and recurrent patterns in time series.
The data sets examined are often large.
Process  determining the nature and structure of the representation deciding how to quantify and compare how well different representations fit the data choose an algorithmic process to optimize the score function deciding what principples of data management are required to implement the algoirthms efficiently  Regression analysis In the form $Y = aX + B$, with X as a predictor variable and Y as a response variable.
In this situation, the score function is the sum of squared discrepancies between the predicted value and the observed value. $$ \sum_{i=1}^{n}(X_i-\bar{X})^2 $$ with $n$ being the number of observations.
The nature of data sets high level  at the simplest level: n observations and p attributes quantitative and categorical measurements  types of structures: models and patterns  model:global summary of a dataset pattern: local patterns  data mining tasks exploratory data analysis  interactive and visual  descriptive modeling  density estimation descriptions include models probability distribution cluster analysis and segmentation partitioning of the p-dimensional space dependency modeling describes the relationship between variables  predictive modeling: classification and regression

from observational datasets to find unsuspected relations and to summarize the data in novel ways

content:
Excerpts from American Affairs' The Real Class War. Note that this post is literally me taking notes (more like copying verbatim) of what the author wrote and I have absolutely no rights to the material provided. Don’t @ me.
 The working class has experienced economic stagnation and precarity, and even life expectancy in the US, as well as ower family stability and civic engagement. Social mobility has declined, while inequality has widened. [the working class] has scarecely any political agency in the current system and no apparent means for acquiring any. At most, working-class voters can cast their votes but can exercise no influence on policy formation, agency personnel, governance areas (that have been trasnferred to technocratic bodies?) While a restive working class might provide fertile ground for political upheavals, any fundamental transformation of Western politics will necessarily be led by increasing numbers of the “elite” who defect and rethink their allegiance to establishment paradigms. 4.Conventional narratives, including many that are critical of the status quo, paint the elite as a unified block aligned with neoliberalism. But the neoliberal economy has created a profound fracture within the elite, the significance of which is just beginning to be felt. The socioeconomic divide that will determine the future of politics, particularly in the US, is not between the top X percent and the rest (1% vs 99%). The real class war is between the 0.1 percent and (at most) the 10 percent. Precisely, between elites primarily dependent on capital gains and those primarily dependent on professional labor. At bottom, the economy that has been constructed over the last few decades is nothing more than a capital accumulation economy. As long as returns on capital exceed returns on labor, then the largest capital holders benefit the most, inequality rises, and wealth becomes more and more narrowly concentrated. Marxian thinkers have been analyzing theses dynamics for almost two centuries, but they have often misread the political effects of these developments, which play out primariliy among the elite managerial class, rather than within the binary of capitalists and proletarians. Lost amid the celabrations of the “information economy” in recent decades is the fact that elite career trajectories are no longer what they used to be.  Big Law associate salaries at white-shoe firms remained flat from 2007 to 2016.
Finance no longer delivers for the top 5% even though firm profits are high. average compensation for mid-level employees in sales and trading has fallen by half while investment banker salaries have been reduced by one-third
hedge funds returns have been disappointing typical employees can enjoy a comfortable lifestyle but unlikely to accumulate sybstantioal capital themselves private equity is healthier but has become highly competitive and increasingly reliant on financial engineering gimmicks, such as selling companies between funds managed by the same firm
What the fuck does this mean?
 In short, the effects of financialization on the real econ­omy are being replicated within the industry itself—the upward redistribution of rents within a context of overall deceleration.
 Silicon Valley  brightest star in the new economy universe. THE VALLEY HAS NEVER BEEN PARTICULARLY FERTILE FOR THE SALARIED PROFESSIONALS AND “ENGINNERS” HIRED BY THESE COMPANIES, WHO EVEN NOW GENERALLY MAKE LESS THAN THEIR COUNTERPARTS ON WALL STREET OR IN BIG LAW the median salary for US IT workers, who frequently must live in high-priced urban areas, is only $81k increasing numbers of engineers, even at the most prestigious companies, are hired on temprary contracts. when artificial growth model stalls, employees can expect mass layoffs, “anti-hierarchy” propaganda notwithstanding many positions that require advanced degrees, large student loans, living in expensive cities barely pay $100k a year  Other professionals  fare worse career prospects of journalists and academics- ironic casualties of the “information economy”- are declining even more the conspicuous embrace of “elite values” by journalists and academics is often little more than an aspirational attempt to remain connected to an economically distant elite- just as educated millenials' conspicuous consumption of “experiences” often serves as a necessary distraction from the grim reality that most will never be able to own a home. content: You, even while you still have life and light, are as good as dead: you squander the greater part of your time in sleep; you snore when awake; you never stop daydreaming; you are burdened with a mind disturbed by grundless fear; and often you cannot discover what is wrong with you, when, like some drunken wretch, you are buffeted with countless cares on every side and drift along aimlessly in utter bewilderement of mind.

After all, man’s search for happiness might just be man’s search for stimuli.

content:
It’s meta, but I feel like no matter I do, I won’t be able to feel like how I want to feel.
Not that I have achieved a lot and feel empty afterwards. Full disclaimer, I have not achieved a single thing that I wanted to do this year. It’s sad and pathetic but it’s also enlightening, I guess.
It’s enlightening in a way that most people I’ve met feel this way. The memes about doomers (or as boomers affectionately call them fuckin' entitled millenials/gen z) are true. We are sad. We are aimless. We spend more time on the phone than ever before. Our daily hit of dopamine probably comes from a popular social media platform.
Most of us feel that we are not living up to our expectations and that we have to atone for it. While rationally I don’t believe that this is true, we haven’t seen but a modicum of how vast and beautiful this world is. Yet we, or at least I and my friends, condition ourselves to think of our personal developments as an ultimate truth in life. Anyday that we are not working toward that goal is a day wasted. In another word, we are taught to measure our self worth based on our contributions to the world. It wouldn’t be that bad if the byproduct of that thinking is a sense of dread and self-pity if we fail to achieve things we want.
At least that’s what I feel. But feel is an overloaded word. I don’t feel like this as if this is a core belief of mine. I feel like this when I’m tired. I feel aimless like this when I’m not managing my time so that I can spend most of my time doing things that I find meaningful.
To put it in a way that most of my friends can relate, I feel like I’ve been doing the logistics too long. I have been taking classes, learning soft skills, improving myself. Things like those surely lay a good foundation to everything, they are like the tutorial parts of a video game. But it is only there to make sure I know how to play a game. It is inherently unrewarding because its sole purpose is to guy players towards the meaningful part. And I’ve been grinding this tutorial for too long. Or is it? Who knows.
What I’m saying is, I feel like I’m barely touching the tips of the iceberg. Life is more than just waking up, going to class, going to the library to do homework, and writing a blogpost complaining how you’re tired of doing all of those for too long.
But of course, the whole thing that I just said is simply not true. I probably shouldn’t treat my life as either meaningful or meaningless.
It’s funny, I know that what ever I think of right now. Somebody smarter and more educated had thought of this before and had written about it. They had probably come to a better conclusion. Well, I should treat this essay as a concretization of my little system of beliefs when I was 20. I should read more.
In a time of senselessness, what do I seek? Will it be Nietschze, will it be ancient Buddhist texts, will it be Netflix, a talk with one of my friends, or do I just power through all of this all by myself?
Goddamn it, I hate meta questions. I just want to do something rewarding. Something that is beneficial in the long term. At the same time, though, I hate doing grudge work. Why? Because I only live once. I am entitled to wanting stuff and getting it.
I don’t know much about Buddhishm. But I vaguely remember that the moment I’ve asked for the wrong thing, I would spend my life chasing the ephemeral stuff. Well guess what. I’m not trying to live my life the perfect way. I’m going to be a sponge.
Yeah you heard me.
I’m gonna be a sponge.
I’ll listen to what people have to say.
I’ll learn as much as I can.
Ugh, this whole essay just screams I need meds. But I’m not diagnosed with anything, yet. I might need some, though.
Also I’ll start a daily vlog and it’s gonna be sick.
summary:
It’s meta, but I feel like no matter I do, I won’t be able to feel like how I want to feel.
Not that I have achieved a lot and feel empty afterwards. Full disclaimer, I have not achieved a single thing that I wanted to do this year. It’s sad and pathetic but it’s also enlightening, I guess.
It’s enlightening in a way that most people I’ve met feel this way.
title: What I feel

content:
I found myself thinking about what Lee Kuan Yew had to say about many things a lot recently. While I know close to nothing about him, I can imagine that most of his thoughts and actions stemmed from a systemic and practical approach.
I remember reading him stating that while he takes a certain liking to some ideas, he is only interested in what works in real life. This Machiavellian approach to problems reminds me of one of Charlie Munger’s lessons in life: avoid extremely intense ideology.
Extreme ideologies are really appealing to young people like us. I don’t exactly know why but my guess is that most young people are trying to find a place in the world for themselves. Ideologies help many people mentally work out their place in the world, how they can work towards something meaningful, and most importantly, how they can be a part of something bigger than themselves.
I know this is a funny thing to say, but public version of Lee Kuan Yew is someone I aspire to be.
Aside from his political side, I like how he navigates around life. Mr Lee appears to be one of the few affluent politicians with a wide range of personality. He is known to have said controversial things, written controversial essays, and held many politically incorect opinions. I can see him as the Jordan Peterson of politics. He is not afraid of public opinion.
People see him in different ways but I believe that’s how he wants to be seen. He probably doesn’t like being a likable figure throughout his lifetime and then have somebody put words in his mouth posthumously for some political gains.
The most interesting thing is, he has his ways with words. I don’t doubt for a second the complexity of his ideas but he always manages to communicate them effectively. Who knows, maybe his clarity of ideas is the reason for his government’s competence. When everybody is required to say what they mean and do what they say, that could help clear the logistics up a little bit.
What a life he lived!
summary:
I found myself thinking about what Lee Kuan Yew had to say about many things a lot recently. While I know close to nothing about him, I can imagine that most of his thoughts and actions stemmed from a systemic and practical approach.
I remember reading him stating that while he takes a certain liking to some ideas, he is only interested in what works in real life. This Machiavellian approach to problems reminds me of one of Charlie Munger’s lessons in life: avoid extremely intense ideology.
title: on Lee Kuan Yew

content:
Hello world. Hi, I’m going to try to blog again. From my experience from past attempts, I can’t keep up with writing essays if I only treat it as a ‘feels good’ activity when I procrastinate. Now that I know better, I will actually put self-imposed deadlines to churn out content for this blog.
Who knows what to make of this decision. I’m in part hopeful that I will try to do my research and write interesting articles.
Or I might half-ass my way to meet the deadlines. That’s more likely the case,but hey, at least you guys know that I tried and failed and laugh at me.
Anyway, I’m thinking of structuring my blog like this:
Most of it will be personal.
Some will be technical.
I will sprinkle some juicy book reviews every now and then.
At the time of writing, I’m thinking of incorporating a commenting system. It will allow everybody on technical essays and only my close friends and my family on personal posts.
I hope this blog will outlive me and reach further than I physically could.
Ah let’s do this together!
